meaning: An unreal cure all drug
Hypothetical disease curing drug
examples: They thought of it as Panacea since it filled all the gaps in their life.
origin: Panacea is the name of an ancient Greed Goddess of Healing. Stem of panakḗs “all-healing” (pan-all + akḗs- a cure)

meaning: Not having enough money to pay for necessities
examples: Gambling would make your landlord throw you out for being impecunious.

meaning: a state of uncertainty, or perplexity, or puzzlement
a dilemma as to do what
examples: Washington faces a similar quandary in Year 2 of its rebuild under Rivera.

meaning: open to or having several possible meanings or interpretations
of doubtful or uncertain nature; difficult to comprehend, distinguish, or classify
examples: Washington faces a similar quandary in Year 2 of its rebuild under Rivera.
origin: from ambi- prefix meaning “both, around” + -igere combining form of agere “to drive, lead, act”

meaning: expert or nimble in the use of the hands or body.
cleverly skillful, resourceful, or ingenious
examples: There was no applause as the little man outwitted his follower by an adroit dodge under the ticket wagon.
origin: First recorded in french to mean 'elegant', 'skillful'

meaning: constant in application or effort; working diligently at a task; persevering; industrious; meticulous
constant; unremitting
examples: Any life, despite the most assiduous biographer’s investigations, remains somewhat of a mystery.
origin: from Latin assiduus, equivalent to assid(ēre) “to sit near or beside, dwell close to”

meaning: not genuine, authentic, or true; not from the claimed, pretended, or proper source; counterfeit.
of illegitimate birth; bastard
examples: President Obama repeated the spurious gender wage gap statistic in his State of the Union address.

meaning: extended to great, unnecessary, or tedious length; long and wordy.
examples: Glenn Greenwald is raising a stink about this in his usual prolix way, and so on and so on.

meaning: churlishly rude or bad-tempered
churlishly rude or bad-tempered
dark or dismal; menacing; threatening
examples: Cramped seats, mask requirements and surly service aren’t the worst part of international airline travel.

meaning: spread throughout
examples: That will mean pervasive discounting with a side of free shipping to coax shoppers to buy.

meaning: Wealthy person
examples: Shadow and Bone’s opulent settings and production design work against it, because the story isn’t rich enough to fill it.

meaning: unmoved by persuasion, pity or tender feelings
stubborn
unyielding
examples: Yet instead of scaling back their political ambitions in the face of an obdurate reality, they are escalating them.

meaning: dormat as an hibernating animal
sluggish
examples: They were torpid, as you or I might be if we’d spent a long period locked-down and socially isolated.

meaning: Known or understood by very few
examples: The bills are long and complex, with arcane differences around industry policy, licensing and other details.
origin: Latin arcānus, equivalent to arc(ēre) to shut up, keep (derivative of arca a chest, box)

meaning: the lowest point; point of greatest adversity or despair.
examples: At their nadir in April, total hours worked were 16% lower than January in both countries.

meaning: to walk heavily or move laboriously; trudge
a sound of a heavy tread.
examples: The tunes might be used to bang the drum to, but they provide a plodding pulse for American stamina.

meaning: a person whose life is devoted to the pursuit of pleasure and self-gratification.
examples: The old Don was a loving father and husband, and a hedonist.

meaning: the state or quality of being wary.
examples: With the wariness was something like question, and almost disbelief.

meaning: horseman, especially a knight
disdainful; unceremonious
to be haughty
examples: The metrics are good, and I don’t say that with a cavalier attitude.

meaning: o speak of or treat slightingly; depreciate; belittle
examples: The greater Wine’s popular appeal grew, the more Museveni disparaged him.
